Event.name: Reserving
Event.definition:
<def-root>In this frame, a <fen>Booker</fen> brings about a situation where an <fen>Organization</fen> plans to provide <fen>Services</fen> to a <fen>Client</fen> at a particular <fen>Scheduled_time</fen>. The <fen>Organization</fen> has authority over when <fen>Services</fen> are provided to whom. The <fen>Booker</fen> usually has to communicate and negotiate with the <fen>Organization</fen> to plan the <fen>Services</fen> for a mutually agreeable <fen>Scheduled_time</fen>. Usually, there is a <fen>Payment</fen> as well.
<ex><fex name="Booker">We</fex> can <t>book</t> <fex name="Client">you</fex> <fex name="Services">a boatride on the Somme or a special tour of the Louvre</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Time">Now</fex> <t>booking</t> <fex name="Services">trips to Cancun</fex><fex name="Payment">for only $50</fex> ! <fex name="Booker">CNI</fex> <fex name="Client">INI</fex></ex>
In many cases, the <fen>Booker</fen> may be the same as the <fen>Client</fen> or the <fen>Organization</fen>. <ex></ex> When the <fen>Booker</fen> is also the <fen>Organization</fen> providing the service, as in the first sentence below, we annotate <fen>Booker</fen> on the first layer and <fen>Organization</fen> on the second. Realizing that the <fen>Booker</fen> is also the <fen>Organization</fen> providing the service is an inference, as we can see by comparing the following two examples. In the first, it seems clear that the hotel is providing the service. In the second, it is clear that the hotel is not providing the service.
<ex><fex name="Booker">The hotel</fex> gave <fex name="Client">us</fex> a <t>reservation</t> <fex name="Services">for two nights</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Booker">The hotel</fex> <m>gave</m> <fex name="Client">us</fex> a <t>reservation</t> <fex name="Services">for two nights</fex> <fex name="Organization">at the adjacent hotel</fex> <fex name="Purpose">to make up for screwing up our original booking</fex> .</ex>
<ex></ex> In the frequent case where the <fen>Booker</fen> is the same as the <fen>Client</fen>, we annotate <fen>Booker</fen> on the first layer and <fen>Client</fen> on the second. <fen>Client</fen> is on the second layer since, in most cases, it is an inference that may be wrong. For example, in the following sentence, the annotation indicates that Patrick is the <fen>Client</fen>. However, it is also possible that Patrick is reserving a table for a party that doesn't even include himself:
<ex><fex name="Booker">Patrick</fex> tried to <t>reserve</t> <fex name="Services">a table</fex> <fex name="Organization">at Dorsia</fex> <fex name="Scheduled_time"> for 7:00</fex> .</ex> <ex><fex name="Client">Patrick</fex> tried to <t>reserve</t> a table at Dorsia for 7:00 .</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Client
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The entity that is intended to receive the <fen>Services</fen> of the <fen>Organization</fen>.
<ex>Phil Collins <t>booked</t> his <fex name="Client">cockatoo</fex> into a $350-a-night pet hotel.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Services
Arg.definition: <def-root>The goods or labor that the <fen>Client</fen> requests the <fen>Organization</fen> preserve for future consumption or rendering.</def-root>

Arg.name: Organization
Arg.definition: <def-root>The entity that enters into its records the request of the <fen>Client</fen> to retain <fen>Services</fen> in the future.</def-root>

Arg.name: Scheduled_time
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The future point in time when the <fen>Client</fen> arranges for the <fen>Organization</fen> to provide <fen>Services</fen>.
<ex>She <t>reserved</t> the room for the meeting <fex name="Scheduled_time">for Tuesday</fex> .</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Booker
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The entity that contacts the <fen>Organization</fen> directly. In many if not most cases, a <fen>Booker</fen> is also a <fen>Client</fen>, but the roles may also be separated, e.g. a travel agent.
<ex>The hotel reserved two rooms for me . </ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Manner
Arg.definition: <def-root>Any description of the event as a whole ("the same way") or a characteristic of the <fen>Booker</fen> during the action that holistically affects the event ("sloppily").</def-root>

Arg.name: Purpose
Arg.definition: <def-root>The situation that the <fen>Booker</fen> intends to bring about by reserving.</def-root>

Arg.name: Means
Arg.definition: <def-root>An action or methodology used by the <fen>Booker</fen> to bring the reservation about.</def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The time at which the reserving event takes place.
<ex>I booked the room for Monday <fex name="Time">only on Tuesday</fex> .</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Payment
Arg.definition: <def-root>The amount paid to the <fen>Organization</fen> in exchange for the <fen>Services</fen>.</def-root>

lexUnit.name: reserve.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: arrange for (a seat, ticket, etc.) to be kept for the use of a particular person.

lexUnit.name: reservation.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the action of reserving. > an arrangement whereby something has been reserved.

lexUnit.name: booking.n
lexUnit.definition: FN: arrangement to receive a service at a particular time.
